text: A three-term arithmetic progression is a sequence of numbers \( (a, b, c) \) such that \( b-a = c-b \), implying \( b = \frac{a+c}{2} \). text: A natural candidate is an increasing sequence of equally spaced numbers. Let's consider the sequence \( 1, 2, 3, \ldots, n \). This integer \( b \) will be part of the sequence \( 1, 2, \ldots, n \) if \( a \) and \( c \) are both either odd or even (since only then is their average an integer).

text: For an arithmetic progression with an odd first and last term, the middle term will also be odd. So, if there are \( m \) odd numbers, we can choose two of them in \( \binom{m}{2} \) ways.
